Received 19 July 1995; revised 16 November 1995: accepted 16 November 1995 Abstract The adsorption of CO, the interaction and the reaction of CO and water have been investigated over supported Ir catalysts. The adsorption of CO was studied by infrared spectroscopy. The 1 dominant spectral features for Ir/Al203 at 298 K are the bands at 2090, 2060, and 2018 cm but on Ir/TiO2, Ir/SiO2, and Ir/MgO only a band at 2060-2075 cm- t was detected. At higher temperature above 473 K CO induces the agglomeration of Ir, but the H20 hindered this process. In the interaction and in the reaction of CO and water, formate formation was observed on the surface of the catalysts. The IR spectra of the adsorbed CO in the presence of water differed from that observed during the adsorption of CO; the band due to linearly bonded CO was shifted to lower wavenumbers. The reaction of CO + H20 was studied in a fixed-bed continuous-flow reactor. The production of H2, CO2 (with ratio about 1) and small amount of hydrocarbons proceeded readily above 523 K. Ir/TiO2 was found to be the most effective catalyst, its activity was 20 times higher than that of the last effective Ir/SiO2. Possible mechanisms of the CO + H20 reaction are discussed. Introduction The reaction of CO and H20, the water-gas shift reaction (CO + H20 CO2 + H2) is an important industrial process. It is used to produce hydrogen, to adjust the H2/CO ratio of synthesis gas and to detoxify gases. The catalysis of this reaction has been the subject of many theoretical and practical investigations. The results obtained on traditional iron, copper and molybdenum based industrial catalysts have been reviewed [1]. Relatively little attention has been paid so far to the reaction on supported noble metals. Grenoble et al. [2] compared the activity of alumina supported Group VII B VIII and IB metals. They found that the most effective noble metal was Ru and the least active one was Ir. The catalytic reaction of water with carbon monoxide to form hydrocarbons and carbon dioxide, known as the KSlbel-Engelhardt reaction [3,4], was studied recently on different supported Rh catalysts [5-7]. Rh/TiO2 was found to be a very active catalyst for CH4 formation in the CO + H20 reaction and its catalytic activity was enhanced by the presence of Pt [7]. Recently there is a renewed interest in the water-gas shift reaction [8-11], because exhaust gases contain permanently 10-12% of water which can convert carbon monoxide to carbon dioxide. In this paper we give a detailed account of the catalytic behaviour of Ir in the CO + H20 reaction. Special attention is focused on the surface process, on the identification of surface species formed during the reaction and on the effect of various supports. This work is connected with our earlier studies of reverse water-gas shift reaction on different supported Pt metals [12-15]. 2. Experimental 2.1. Materials The catalysts were prepared by impregnating the support with the solution of H2IrC16 salt to yield a nominal 5% metal. The following oxides were used: "y-A1203, (Degussa P110 C1, 100 m2/g), TiO2 (Degussa P25, it is a mixture of anatase and rutile, the BET area is 150 m2/g), SiO2 (Cab-O-Sil, 200 m2/g), and MgO (DAB 6, 170 m2/g). The latter two oxides are amorphous. The preparation method of the catalysts has been described in detail elsewhere [12,14]. For catalytic studies small fragments of slightly compressed pellets were used. For IR spectroscopic measurements the powdered material was pressed into a 10 30 mm self-supporting disk. Before the catalytic measurements the samples were oxidised for 30 min and reduced in hydrogen flow for 60 min at 673 K in situ. After oxidation and A. Erd6helyi et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 139 (1996) 131-147 133 reduction the sample was evacuated or flushed with inert gas for 15 min at 673 K, and then it was cooled to the reaction temperature in vacuum or in flowing inert gas. The characteristic data for the supported Ir samples are shown in Table 1. The gases used were initially of commercial purity. He (99.996%), N2 (99.995%) and Ar (99.99%) were deoxygenated with an oxytrap. CO (99.995%) was used as received. 2.2. Methods Catalytic investigations were carried out in a fixed-bed flow reactor made of a 15-mm-id quartz tube. Its length was 240 ram, the dead volume was filled with glass beads. The amount of catalysts used was 0.5 g, the space velocities were 3000-6000 h-1. The exit gases were analyzed gas chromatographically (Chro- repack 9001) on a Porapak QS column by thermal conductivity and flame ionisation detectors. The water introduced into the reactor was that resulting after bubbling a mixture of Ar + CO through preheated water. The water concentration was usually about 15%. The pulse reactor was an 8-mm-id quartz tube which was incorporated between the sample inlet and the column of the gas chromatograph (Hewlett- Packard 5710). One pulse contained 16.4/~mol of gases. Usually a 0.3 g sample was used and the dead volume of the reactor was filled with quartz beads. The infrared spectroscopic studies were made in a vacuum cell using a self supporting wafer which underwent the same pre-treatment as the catalysts. The spectra were recorded with a Specord 75 IR Zeiss Jena double-beam spectrome- ter. The dispersions of the supported metals were determined from the H2 consumption, as in our previous papers [12,14], by H2 adsorption and by H~ -O~_ titration at 298 K using the pulse technique. 3. Adsorption of CO on supported Ir Although the adsorption of CO on supported Pt metals has been the subject of several studies, the CO-Ir interaction has received relatively little attention. Lynds [18] observed only one band at 2070 cm-~ following CO adsorption on Ir/A1203. Guerra and Schulman [19] found strong bands at 2030 and 2080 cm-1 and weaker ones at 1993 and 1890-1920 cm 1 for Ir/SiO2. Howe [20] and Solymosi and Rask6 [21] identified two CO bands at 2060-2080 and 2020 cm-1 for reduced Ir/A1203 and Ir/SiO2 and attributed them to linearly bonded CO to larger and smaller Ir clusters, respectively. Mc Vicker et al. [22] stated that the highly dispersed catalysts display a major carbonyl band at 2060 cm-1, while the larger crystallites exhibit a band at 2020-2025 cm-~. Toolenaar et al. [23] suggested that the band at 2050 cm-1 represents the adsorption of CO on 'low-coordinate' sites (edges, comers, etc.), the high frequency band at 2080 cm-~ is due to CO adsorbed on 'high-coordinated' sites. Tanaka et al. [24] observed the pair of bands at 2080-2070 and 2008-1995 cm ~ on A1203 and SiO2 supported Ir4(CO)12. These bands were assigned to a dicarbonyl complex. Solymosi et al. [25] found that the dominant spectral features for low tempera- ture reduced Ir/AI203 after adsorption of CO at 300 K are the bands at 2090-2107 and 2010-2037 cm-1. On the high temperature reduced sample the adsorption of CO at 300 K produces a broad band peaking at around 2060 cm-j, but after an extended adsorption time bands at 2090-2107 and 2010-2037 cm-1 appear and grow in intensity. This process is attributed to the oxidative disruption of IrX crystallites and to the formation of isolated iridium sites which involves the participation of OH groups of the support. When the sample was heated up to 673 K in the presence of CO the reductive agglomeration of Ir(I) sites was observed [25]. The same features were also detected in the case of supported Rh [26] and Ru [27]. In the case of our Ir/Al203 after the adsorption of CO at room temperature, bands at 2090, 2060, 2018 cm-1 were observed. Taking into account the above assignments we can state that on Ir/AleO3 Ir-dicarbonyl and Ir-CO were found. The assignation of the bands at 2080 cm-l and 2018 cm-l to dicarbonyl species is supported by the recent observation that [Ir(CO)2 (acac)] in hexane solution has two strong IR absorption bands at 2073 cm-1 and 1998 cm-1 [28]. On other supported Ir samples we obtained only a broad peak at about 2070 cm-1. It means that in these cases only the linearly bonded CO was formed. A. ErdShelyi et al. / Applied Catalysis A: General 139 (1996) 131-147 143 These results are in agreement with the dispersion data of the catalysts (Table 1). The Ir-dicarbonyl, which requires highly dispersed metal [25], was formed on Ir/Al203 where the dispersion was 59% and in the other cases, when the ratio of surface metal atoms was less than 35%, only the Ir-CO form was detected. As demonstrated in Fig. 1 on Ir/A1203 the absorption band intensities of Ir-dicarbonyl species decreased above 473 K and at the same time a new form, absorbing at about 2015 cm-J, was formed. On the other supported Ir samples a band at 2020 cm ~ was detected at higher temperature (at 623 K) instead of the band at 2070 cm-i. Taking into account the earlier suggestion [21,22] the band at about 2020 cm-~ can be assigned to the CO bonded to large Ir crystallites. These results clearly indicated the CO induced transformation of Ir crystallites. In the presence of water vapour similar spectral changes were observed (Fig. 3), but in these cases the intensity decay of the linearly bonded CO was more pronounced and above 623 K two peaks at 2025 cm ~ and at about 1970 cm- were observed on the spectra. We believe that the appearance of these bands at such low wavenumbers is primarily caused by the formation of Ir-carbonyl-hy- dride (Ir/c bonded to large and small lr crystallites. We believe that the coverage effect on the position of the linear CO bands plays only a minor role. These spectra revealed that in the presence of water vapour the small Ir clusters are stable on the surface. It means that the water hindered the CO induced Ir agglomeration. The same feature was also observed on supported Rh [26]. When a CO + H20 mixture was added to the Ir/AI203 at room temperature and the sample was heated to different temperatures (Fig. 4) (the infrared spectra were taken at the temperature of the adsorption) the same spectral changes were observed in the CO region, only the band intensities were stronger above 573 K. In these cases above 473 K bands at 1590 cm-L and 1380 cm-~ were also detected which can be assigned to the O-C-O stretching vibrations of formate ion. The formation of formate ion in the water-gas shift and in the reverse water-gas shift (H2 + CO2) reaction was determined earlier not only on sup- ported metals [9,17,29], but also on A1203 [30] and MgO [31] alone. It was demonstrated that the formate ion is located not on the metal, but rather on the support [ 17]. 4.2. The catalytic reaction between CO and H20 The main products of the water-gas shift reaction were CO2 and H2. On Ir/A1203 methane and on Ir/TiO2 methane, ethane, ethylene and C3-hydro- carbons were also detected. The turnover frequency for CO2 formation determined on Ir/A1203 (2.6. 10 3 s-~) was almost the same as reported by Grenoble et al. [2] for CO consumption on 2% Ir/A1203 (3.2 10-3 S t). The activation energies for CO~ and H2 formation are also in good agreement with the data obtained by Grenoble et al. [2]. IR spectroscopic measurements revealed that the adsorbed 144 A. Erd6helyi et al. / Applied Catalysis A: General 139 (1996) 131-147 CO is still stable at the temperature of the reaction in the presence of water vapour (Fig. 4). Formation of formate ions were also detected but these species are bonded to the support, rather than to the metal. The formation of formate ion in the reverse water-gas shift reaction has been discussed in detail on supported Rh catalysts [17,31]. It was supposed that the hydrogen activated on the metal reacts with CO2 and a part of the formate decomposes on the metal. The remaining formates migrate from the Rh onto the support. Another mechanism was also discussed, namely that H spills over to the support and reacts with bicarbonate bonded on the support [17]. In the CO + H20 reaction the formate can form in the following reaction CO(a) + OH(a) --~ HCOO(a) The CO is bonded to the metal and reacts with the OH group located on the metal support interface. The formate bonded to the metal spills over to the support, or it decomposes to CO2 and H~a). The latter reaction takes place more often. HCOOc.) -~ CO2 q'- He.) 2H) ~ H2 Carbon dioxide cannot adsorb on Ir single crystals [32] or on polycrystalline Ir above 200 K [33,34], so in the temperature range of the reaction the CO2 formed desorbs immediately. The dominant process in the decomposition of formic acid on metal catalysts is the dehydrogenation reaction and on oxides it is the dehydration [35]. Niwa and Lunsford [6] presumed that in the water-gas shift reaction the first step on supported Rh catalysts is the dissociation of CO and the surface carbon plays an important role. The dissociation of CO on supported Ir is a relatively slow process compared with the rate of the reaction so in this case it may not be the determining step. Iwasawa et al. determined the formation of formate ion in the CO + H20 reaction on oxides [36,10,11], and on supported Rh catalysts [9]. They assumed and established that the decomposition of formate located on the oxides to carbon dioxide is promoted by the H20. We can not rule out this process, but we assume that the contribution of this reaction is not significant compared with the reaction occurring on the metals. The dominant role of the reaction on the metal can be explained as: 1. although the supports are not totally inactive, the reaction rates are several orders of magnitude less than those on supported metal. 2. the formate ion is not stable on SiO2 [31], but the reaction occurred with a significant rate on Ir/SiO2 catalysts, (Table 1) 3. the reaction orders are nearly the same on Ir/TiO2 and on Ir/SiO2 (Fig. 7), although the formate can form on TiO2 supported catalyst, but not on SiO2 supported one. A. Erd6helyi et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 139 (1996) 131-147 145 The question arises as to whether the OH group formation in the water dissociation occurred on the metal or on the support. We assume that the support has a much stronger effect toward reactions requiring activation of H20, supporting the notion that water is principally activated on support sites, but the water-gas shift reaction takes place mostly on the metal and the metal-support interface. Grenoble et al. [2] excluded the latter suggestion. They compared the turnover frequencies on Rh/A1203 with different dispersion, and it was found that the rate was essentially constant over a wide range of metal dispersions. Our IR spectroscopic measurements revealed (Fig. 3) that in the presence of water vapour the band intensity of the linearly bonded CO decreased and the intensity of bicarbonyl species remained the same compared with the spectra taken in vacuum (Fig. 1). It was earlier demonstrated that Ir(CO)2 species formed on the highly dispersed metal [20], but we found that these species are not active in the water-gas shift reaction. It means that the small metal particles have a higher metal-support interface, but these centres are occupied partly by inactive CO with respect to the reaction. On the other hand it was recently demonstrated that the Rh surface is agglomerated [26] in the presence of CO at high temperature, i.e. the dispersion of metal decreased. So we do not exclude the reaction on the metal-support interface. In the CO + H20 reaction on Ir/A1203 and especially on Ir/TiO2, CH4, C2- and C3-hydrocarbons were also formed. There are different possible routes for the formation of hydrocarbons. The CO or CO2 can react with hydrogen formed in the reaction. Earlier it was suggested that CO [37] and CO2 [14] hydrogena- tion on supported Rh occurs through the formation of Rh-carbonyl-hydride, in which the CO can easily dissociate, and the surface carbon formed in this process was hydrogenated to CH4. In the CO + H,O interaction we supposed the carbonyl-hydride formation and we have no reason to suggest another route for the CH4 evolution than the formation of surface carbon from the (Ir(~" species which is hydrogenated to methane. The rate of the CO + H20 reaction on the iridium catalyst was very sensitive to the nature of the support. This is in harmony with the results obtained on Rh [6,8] or Pt [2]. On the basis of specific activity Ir/TiO2 is the most effective catalyst, followed by Ir/MgO, Ir/Al203, Ir/SiO2. The differences in the specific activity of the last three samples, however, are very slight, if any. The rate determined on Ir/TiO2 exceeded by more than one order of magnitude that of the less active Ir/SiO2 (Table 1). Similar results were obtained in the CO2 + CH4 reaction on supported iridium catalysts [38]. It can not be excluded that the high activity of Ir/TiO2 is associated with the interaction between the lr and the support [39] which increases the back donation of electrons from Ir into the anti-bonding orbital of carbon monoxide, thereby facilitating its reaction with OH groups. To interpret the high efficiency of the TiO2 has to be taken into consideration that during the pre-treatment of the samples, the titania may 146 A. We supposed that some steps of the reaction probably take place on the metal-support interface and these centres may be also active in the reaction. 5. Conclusion 1. The adsorption of CO at 298 K on Ir/A1203 produces three absorption bands at 2090, 2060, and 2018 cm-1. On Ir/MgO on Ir/TiO2 and on Ir/SiO2 only a band at 2060-2075 cm-~ was detected. At higher tempera- ture above 473 K CO induces the agglomeration of Ir, but the H20 hindered this process. 2. In the interaction and in the reaction of CO and water Ir-carbonyl-hydride and formate formation was observed on the surface of the catalysts. 3. The reaction of CO and water occurred readily above 523 K to produce H2 and CO2 (ratio with about 1) and small amounts of hydrocarbons. Ir/TiO2 was found to be the most effective catalyst. The adsorption of CO, the interaction and the reaction of CO and water have been investigated over supported Ir catalysts. The adsorption of CO was studied by infrared spectroscopy. The dominant spectral features for Ir/Al2O3 at 298 K are the bands at 2090, 2060, and 2018 cm−1 but on Ir/TiO2, Ir/SiO2, and Ir/MgO only a band at 2060–2075 cm−1 was detected. At higher temperature above 473 K CO induces the agglomeration of Ir, but the H2O hindered this process. In the interaction and in the reaction of CO and water, formate formation was observed on the surface of the catalysts. The IR spectra of the adsorbed CO in the presence of water differed from that observed during the adsorption of CO; the band due to linearly bonded CO was shifted to lower wavenumbers. The reaction of CO + H2O was studied in a fixed-bed continuous-flow reactor. The production of H2, CO2 (with ratio about 1) and small amount of hydrocarbons proceeded readily above 523 K. Ir/TiO2 was found to be the most effective catalyst, its activity was 20 times higher than that of the last effective Ir/SiO2. Possible mechanisms of the CO + H2O reaction are discussed.
